texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Amateur radio  is a fun way to mess around with technology, meet new people, and communicate off the grid. Talking directly to another radio on a single frequency (also called  simplex ) is the easiest way to get started. However, it can be difficult to communicate over longer distances without amplifiers, proper wiring, and antennas. This is where a radio repeater can help.
texts.text: Amateur radio  is a fun way to mess around with technology, meet new people, and communicate off the grid. Talking directly to another radio on a single frequency (also called  simplex ) is the easiest way to get started. However, it can be difficult to communicate over longer distances without amplifiers, proper wiring, and antennas. This is where a radio repeater can help.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: What's in scope
texts.text: What's in scope

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This post is focused on fairly local communication on VHF/UHF bands. The most common frequencies for local communication in these bands are:
texts.text: This post is focused on fairly local communication on VHF/UHF bands. The most common frequencies for local communication in these bands are:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 2 meters (~144-148MHz)*
texts.text: 2 meters (~144-148MHz)*

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 70 centimeters (~420-450MHz)*
texts.text: 70 centimeters (~420-450MHz)*

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: NOTE: Always consult the  band plan  for your area to see which part of the frequency band you could and should use.
texts.text: NOTE: Always consult the  band plan  for your area to see which part of the frequency band you could and should use.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Of course, you can do some amazing things with weak signal VHF (which can be used to commuinicate over  great  distances), but we're not talking about that here. The  HAMSter Amateur Radio Group  is a great place to get started with that.
texts.text: Of course, you can do some amazing things with weak signal VHF (which can be used to commuinicate over  great  distances), but we're not talking about that here. The  HAMSter Amateur Radio Group  is a great place to get started with that.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: We're also not talking about radio bands longer than 2 meters (which includes high frequency (HF) bands). Some of those bands require advanced FCC licensing that takes additional studying and practice.
texts.text: We're also not talking about radio bands longer than 2 meters (which includes high frequency (HF) bands). Some of those bands require advanced FCC licensing that takes additional studying and practice.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Keeping it simple(x)
texts.text: Keeping it simple(x)

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Simplex radio  involves communication where radios are tuned to a single frequency and only one radio can transmit at a time. This is like a simple walkie-talkie. If one person is transmitting, everyone else listens. If someone else tries to transmit at the same time, then the waves will be garbled and nobody will be able to hear either person. This is often called "doubling up".
texts.text: Simplex radio  involves communication where radios are tuned to a single frequency and only one radio can transmit at a time. This is like a simple walkie-talkie. If one person is transmitting, everyone else listens. If someone else tries to transmit at the same time, then the waves will be garbled and nobody will be able to hear either person. This is often called "doubling up".

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This method works well when radios are in range of each other without a bunch of objects in between. However, it's difficult to talk via simplex over great distances or around big obstables, such as mountains or hills.
texts.text: This method works well when radios are in range of each other without a bunch of objects in between. However, it's difficult to talk via simplex over great distances or around big obstables, such as mountains or hills.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Repeaters
texts.text: Repeaters

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Repeaters  are a little more complex to use, but they provide some great benefits. A repeater usually consists of one or two radios, one or two antennas, duplexers, and some other basic equipment. They receive a signel on one frequency and broadcast that same signal on another frequency. They often are mounted high on towers and this gives them a much better reach than antennas on your car or home.
texts.text: Repeaters  are a little more complex to use, but they provide some great benefits. A repeater usually consists of one or two radios, one or two antennas, duplexers, and some other basic equipment. They receive a signel on one frequency and broadcast that same signal on another frequency. They often are mounted high on towers and this gives them a much better reach than antennas on your car or home.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I enjoy using a repeater here in San Antonio called  KE5HBB . The repeater has this configuration:
texts.text: I enjoy using a repeater here in San Antonio called  KE5HBB . The repeater has this configuration:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Downlink: 145.370
texts.text: Downlink: 145.370

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Uplink: 144.770
texts.text: Uplink: 144.770

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Offset: -0.6 MHz
texts.text: Offset: -0.6 MHz

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Uplink Tone: 114.8
texts.text: Uplink Tone: 114.8

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Downlink Tone: 114.8
texts.text: Downlink Tone: 114.8

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Let's make sense of this data:
texts.text: Let's make sense of this data:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Downlink: This is the frequency that the repeater uses to
texts.text: Downlink: This is the frequency that the repeater uses to

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Uplink: The receiver
texts.text: Uplink: The receiver

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Offset: This tells you how to calculate the uplink frequency if it is not
texts.text: Offset: This tells you how to calculate the uplink frequency if it is not

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Uplink/Downlink Tones: Your radio must transmit this tone to
texts.text: Uplink/Downlink Tones: Your radio must transmit this tone to

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Opening the squelch
texts.text: Opening the squelch

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Transmitting radio waves uses a lot of power and it creates a lot of heat. There are parts of a radio that will wear out much more quickly if a radio is transmitting constantly. This is why receivers have a  squelch . This means that a radio must transmit something strong enough on the frequency (or use a tone) to let the repeater know that it needs to repeat something.
texts.text: Transmitting radio waves uses a lot of power and it creates a lot of heat. There are parts of a radio that will wear out much more quickly if a radio is transmitting constantly. This is why receivers have a  squelch . This means that a radio must transmit something strong enough on the frequency (or use a tone) to let the repeater know that it needs to repeat something.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You may come across repeaters with no tones listed (sometimes shown as  PL ). This means that you can just transmit on the uplin frequency and the repeater will repeat your signal. These repeaters are easy to use, but they can create problems.
texts.text: You may come across repeaters with no tones listed (sometimes shown as  PL ). This means that you can just transmit on the uplin frequency and the repeater will repeat your signal. These repeaters are easy to use, but they can create problems.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Imagine if you're traveling through an area and you're using a frequency to talk to a friend in another car. As you're driving, you move in range of a repeater that is listening on that frequeny. Suddenly your conversation is now being broadcasted through the repeater and everyone listening to that repeater must listen to you. This isn't what you expected and it could be annoying to other listeners.
texts.text: Imagine if you're traveling through an area and you're using a frequency to talk to a friend in another car. As you're driving, you move in range of a repeater that is listening on that frequeny. Suddenly your conversation is now being broadcasted through the repeater and everyone listening to that repeater must listen to you. This isn't what you expected and it could be annoying to other listeners.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Also, in crowded urban areas, there's always a chance that signals might end up on the repeater's listening frequency unintentionally. That would cause the repeater to start transmitting and it would increase wear.
texts.text: Also, in crowded urban areas, there's always a chance that signals might end up on the repeater's listening frequency unintentionally. That would cause the repeater to start transmitting and it would increase wear.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Two repeaters might be relatively close (or just out of range) and the tone helps each repeater identify its own valid radio traffic.
texts.text: Two repeaters might be relatively close (or just out of range) and the tone helps each repeater identify its own valid radio traffic.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Tuning the tones
texts.text: Tuning the tones

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Most repeaters have a  tone squelch . That means you can blast them with 100 watts of radio waves and they won't repeat a thing until you transmit an inaudible tone at the beginning of your transmission.
texts.text: Most repeaters have a  tone squelch . That means you can blast them with 100 watts of radio waves and they won't repeat a thing until you transmit an inaudible tone at the beginning of your transmission.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: As an example, in the case of KE5HBB, this tone is 114.8. You must configure a  CTCSS  tone on your radio so that the tone is transmitted as soon as you begin transmitting. That signals the repeater that it's time to repeat. These signals aren't audible to humans.
texts.text: As an example, in the case of KE5HBB, this tone is 114.8. You must configure a  CTCSS  tone on your radio so that the tone is transmitted as soon as you begin transmitting. That signals the repeater that it's time to repeat. These signals aren't audible to humans.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If you know you're tuned to the right frequency to transmit (the uplink frequency), but the repeater won't repeat your traffic, then you are most likely missing a tone. There's also a chance that you programmed the uplink and downlink tones into your radio in reverse, so check that, too.
texts.text: If you know you're tuned to the right frequency to transmit (the uplink frequency), but the repeater won't repeat your traffic, then you are most likely missing a tone. There's also a chance that you programmed the uplink and downlink tones into your radio in reverse, so check that, too.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Repeater transmit tone
texts.text: Repeater transmit tone

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Some receivers will transmit a tone when they broadcast back to you, but some won't. If you can transmit but you can't hear anyone else when they talk, double check your radio's settings for a tone squelch on the receiving side. Your radio can also listen for these tones and only open its squelch when it hears them.
texts.text: Some receivers will transmit a tone when they broadcast back to you, but some won't. If you can transmit but you can't hear anyone else when they talk, double check your radio's settings for a tone squelch on the receiving side. Your radio can also listen for these tones and only open its squelch when it hears them.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I usually disable receiver squelch for tones on my radio since the repeater operator could disable that feature at any time and I wouldn't be able to hear any transmissions since my radio would be waiting for the tone.
texts.text: I usually disable receiver squelch for tones on my radio since the repeater operator could disable that feature at any time and I wouldn't be able to hear any transmissions since my radio would be waiting for the tone.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Testing a repeater
texts.text: Testing a repeater

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: First off, please don't test a repeater unless you have a proper amateur radio license in your jurisdiction. In the United States, that's the FCC. Don't skip this step.
texts.text: First off, please don't test a repeater unless you have a proper amateur radio license in your jurisdiction. In the United States, that's the FCC. Don't skip this step.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Once you get your repeater's frequencies programmed into your radio properly and you've double checked the settings for sending tones, you can try "breaking the squelch."
texts.text: Once you get your repeater's frequencies programmed into your radio properly and you've double checked the settings for sending tones, you can try "breaking the squelch."

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Press the transmit button on your radio briefly for about half second and release. You should hear something when you do this. For some repeaters, you may hear a  KERRRCHUNK  noise. That's the sound of the repeater squelch closing the transmission now that you're done with your transmission. On other repeaters, you may hear some audible tones or beeps as soon as you release the transmit button.
texts.text: Press the transmit button on your radio briefly for about half second and release. You should hear something when you do this. For some repeaters, you may hear a  KERRRCHUNK  noise. That's the sound of the repeater squelch closing the transmission now that you're done with your transmission. On other repeaters, you may hear some audible tones or beeps as soon as you release the transmit button.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Once you have it working properly, stop breakng the squelch and introduce yourself! For example, when I'm in my car, I might say:  "W5WUT mobile and monitoring."  That lets people on the repeater know that I'm there and that I'm moving (so I might not be on for a very long time).
texts.text: Once you have it working properly, stop breakng the squelch and introduce yourself! For example, when I'm in my car, I might say:  "W5WUT mobile and monitoring."  That lets people on the repeater know that I'm there and that I'm moving (so I might not be on for a very long time).

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Good luck on the radio waves! 73's from W5WUT.
texts.text: Good luck on the radio waves! 73's from W5WUT.
